name: (2Z)-2-(2-nitrophenyl)-3-phenylprop-2-enoic acid
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1463
Reason: The base unit for comparison will be benzoic acid, with a melting point of 122.4 degrees Celsius. The presence of a phenyl group increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the possibility of π-π stacking interactions, which might contribute an estimated +30 degrees. The presence of the nitro group on the other phenyl ring provides strong inductive electron withdrawal, increasing intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding (if available) and dipole-dipole interactions, estimated to increase the melting point by approximately +40 degrees. The presence of the double bond in the aliphatic chain (prop-2-enoic acid) does not significantly affect the melting point, as it neither increases hydrogen bonding nor presents significant steric hindrance in solid-state packing.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit here is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The introduction of a nitro group generally increases the melting point due to its strong electron-withdrawing nature, which can lead to stronger intermolecular forces such as dipole-dipole interactions. The nitro group can be estimated to increase the melting point by about +80 degrees Celsius. The presence of a conjugated system in the molecule, such as the prop-2-enoic acid moiety, can also increase the melting point due to the rigidity and planarity of the molecule, as well as the potential for additional intermolecular interactions. This conjugated system can be estimated to increase the melting point by about +40 degrees Celsius.
